elements.text: PART ONE
SCENE 1: JOHN'S MIND.
Silence. The following voices and sounds overlap each other.
(Whispers) Can you hear me? (Sniggers) Killer! I know you can hear me! Murderer!'
A cat squeals.
(Whispers) Here, kitty-kitty!
The cat squeals louder then cuts off.
(Whispers) Destroyer!
A woman screams.
(Whispers) I'm in your head!
The voices start to whisper ‘killer’, ‘murderer’ and ‘destroyer’ over and over again — starting off quiet, then getting faster and overlapping ~ then over the top of this...
(Whispers loudly and harshly) I’m in your head! If you can hear me - you're going to die!
(Shouts) No! No! NO!
The whispering voices are loud and almost distorted as JOHN’s scream continues and all merge into... Music: Doctor Who theme — the scary whispering voices continue over the music.
SCENE 2: INT. THE APARTMENT.
The whispering voices merge into a slight hum of traffic and the sound of car horns. We can also hear the sounds of crowds cheering, but quiet, in the distance. After a while we hear a rifle cock.
(Approaching, quietly) I can think of easier ways of making a living, you know.?
What?
DOCTOR A man with your talents; your eye for detail, your vision. A watchmaker. A jeweller, perhaps.
What do you want?
Or you could try keyhole surgery. But here you are now,
ready and aimed. One tiny amount of pressure on the forefinger of your
right hand...
One tiny amount of pressure...
DOCTOR Of course, taking out a head of state isn’t small fry. Oh
no. I mean, it takes skill, preparation, expertise. And someone,
somewhere clearly recognises your talents.
Look, just who are you?
See? Already, life has changed. Questions to be answered.
You allowed yourself to be distracted. So me simply being here has
ohenges: things, hasn’t it? Now, aren’t you wondering who I am, why I’m ere?
You're a madman, aren't you!
You're the one about to commit murder. I'm just here for
the view. Actually, I wanted to tell you a story.
Not now if you don’t mind. I’m a bit busy.
DOCTOR The procession is still halfway down the Mall. You've got time to listen to me and then, if you want, still complete your mission.
Oh, I get it. You’re here to tell me that the person I’m going to kill, well, they’re not that bad really and life is worth living and all that —
Well, let’s see shall we? How about I sit down. I’ve my thermos here. We can have a cup of tea and I can tell you my story. Then, if you still want to fire your gun, you can. How does that sound?
Well...
Yes?
Yes.
They sit down. The DOCTOR unscrews the lid of the thermos and pours 4 cup of tea, which he hands to the man.
There you go. So... let me tell you my story. Well, it’s not really my story. It happened to a friend of mine. (Pauses as his voice becomes serious) A very old friend.
The DOCTOR’s narration continues into the next scene uninterrupted as the SFX merge into...
SCENE 3: INT. THE HALLWAY. Clocks ticking in an old house.
(Voiceover) On the outer edges of an old town called Perfugium, sits an old house. And in that old house, sits an old man. And he sits. And he waits. He waits for the arrival of his—
An old-fashioned doorbell rings.
(Voiceover) And it sounds as if they have arrived. The old man waits in his study as his young maid—
The bell rings again
(Voiceover) — as his young maid leaves her cooking and with patience and a calm smile makes her way to the door to let in her master’s oldest friends.

(Rushing to the door quietly, muttering to herself, not in the least calm or patient) Yes, yes, I heard you. (Starts to pull back the bolts on the door) Hope you keep pulling the bell and it falls onto your- (Then suddenly politely as she opens the door) Inspector Schaeffer. Mrs Schaeffer. Please do come in. The Master is expecting you.
(Rushing in through the door. Full of bluster) Ah! Good evening to you, Jade! Mmm... what is that divine smell?
It’s stuffed venison, sir. May I take your coat, ma’am?
Yes. Thank you, Ja~”
(interrupts) It smells exquisitel Jade, I swear the Empress herself doesn’t eat as well as your master.
takes their coats.
Oh, thank you, sir. Very good of you to say so.
I'm just saying it as it is, girl!
Well, if you'd like to follow me, sir, ma’am, the Master is waiting for you in his study.
Lead on, Jadel Lead on and we shall follow! (SFX: They
start walking) I do hope he’s got the fire alight. It’s a bitter night out ere.
They do say there’s a storm coming, sir.
JACQUELINE A storm?
Don't worry, my love. I think we’ll be well protected from the elements in here.
I was more concerned about my—
Cinterrupts) I think your street urchins will be able to take care of themselves for one night, my sweet.
(Through gritted teeth) Yes. Thank you, Vic-
Cinterrupts) Through here, sir, ma’am. She opens the door to the study and shows them through.
Sir. Your guests have arrived.
(Chuckling) Victor! And my beautiful Jacqueline! How are you? He moves towards them (and us).
Come in. Come in. Thank you, Jade. I'll call you when we're ready to dine.
Very good, sir. She leaves, closing the door behind her.
John, you old rogue. How the devil are you?
Not bad-
(interrupts) Oh, happy birthday, John! (She kisses him) We were worried you were going to cancel this evening's little get- together.°
My dear! And miss out on a night of your companionship? Why ever would I do such a thing?
Well, you haven’t been at the Sanatorium for days! Have you been ill?
Well I-
(Interrupts) Did you have a chill? You should wrap up warmer, you know!
Tam fine. (Laughs) Really, 1 am. I was a little out of sorts but I’m all the better for seeing you two. How are you both?
Muddling along, John. Muddling along.
Where are my manners? Let me pour you both a drink. Wine?
Coh, yes! Some of that delicious red you make yourself.
Now let me just-—
Cinterrupts) Just a small glass for Jacqueline. You know how... flighty she gets.
Come on now, Victor. Tonight is a celebration.
(Interrupts) I think I know my wife best, thank you, dobn.
JOHN Of course, my apologies.
He pours three glasses of wine.
There you go. And there.
Let us drink a toast to our good friend, Doctor John Smith, on this, the night of his birthday!
VICTOR And wishing you many more to come!
They chink their glasses together and drink.

Thank you both. We should also drink a toast to old Woolstencroft for departing this mortal coil and leaving me this huge house and thus the lifestyle to which I am rapidly becoming accustomed. They all laugh.
VICTOR And leaving you a wonderful maid.
Jade?
She’s certainly a pretty young thing, John.
(Has obviously never considered JADE in this way) Yes, I suppose she probably is. I believe she has a young man in town.
Young men never have money or intelligence, though
John. Perhaps you—
(Interrupts) Victor!
Ah... but she doesn't compare to my sweet and charitable Jacqueline. ;
(Quietly) No... (Louder) So you like what I've done with
the study? I've tried to make it a little more homely. I’m afraid old Woolstencroft had an unhealthy obsession with darkness.
Ob, but it’s a wonderful house! So old. Well, apart from the curse!®
Ah, yes, the curse!
Curse?
JOHN The curse! Your beloved wife told me all about it! Bit of a family-
Cinterrupts with a hint of jealously) When?
Oh... ah, just after I inherited the place.
You tell him, John.
Well, you know how Jacqueline’s ancestors, the Uttersons, founded Perfugium many years ago?
How could I forget? Her mother reminds me every time
we meet. (Shrill voice) ‘You've married into the Founding Family, Victor. Moved up the social scale now.
They laugh.

Well, the Uttersons were said to be a devout, disciplined family. Well... most of them. One of them, Sir Joseph Utterson was, I believe, the black sheep of the family. A gambling drunk, he was said to cavort with whores and beggars. His family shunned him, so he built himself this house and continued his life of debauchery within these walls.
Debauchery, eh? Doesn’t sound that bad!

Ah, but then one night he went too far. He procured himself a young girl, plied her with brandy and absinthe, believing her to be one of his ladies of the night. Only she wasn’t. And... during their ‘night of wickedness’ she died. Her father, seeking revenge, slaughtered Sir Joseph and all his servants~
Cinterrupts) And placed a curse on the house that whoever lived here would meet a similar fate?
(Claps her hands) You have heard it!
It's hardly the most original legend, my darling. Superstitious claptrap!
Oh, Victor! You’re no fun! Just think! The ghost of Sir Joseph could be in this very room.
(Behind JACQUELINE’s shoulder) Boo!
John!’
laughs. Very briefly and almost unnoticeably a whispering voice Jaughs along with VICTOR.
(Laughing) I'm afraid my wife has the same ridiculous sensibilities as ever, John. Oh, I nearly forgot. Your present...
Oh, thank you both. Really, I wasn’t expecting...
I wouldn’t get too excited, old man. I’m afraid I've been rather busy with work and so Jacqueline had to choose it. Bound to be some ridiculous, romantic rubbish."
I’m sure it will be excellent. Shall I open it now, or after dinner?
Oh, after dinner! My stomach feels as if my throat has been cut.
The whispering voice, again almost unnoticeable, sniggers as JOHN speaks,
After dinner it is then. If you'll both excuse me, I shall see how Jade is getting on.
VICTOR Of course.
leaves, closing the door.
(Lowered voice) There you go again. Making a fool of yourself, Jacqueline. Fawning over him. He’s not one of your charitable cases.
(Lowered voice) And I see, my dear husband, that you are doing your best to ruin what could be a perfectly wonderful evening. What is the matter with you tonight?"
Oh, Jacqueline, you do know me too well.
Indeed I do. So? What’s wrong?
There’s been... there’s been another murder.
(Shocked) Oh... (quieter) oh, I'm so sorry. Was it the same as the others?
Yes. Another poor young girl. This one wasn’t even a- I had... I had to tell her mother.'”
0h, Victor. 1 am sorry. And was she—
Cnterrupts) Like the others? Yes. All these years as an Adjudicator and I still cannot understand how anybody could do such a thing
JACQUELINE And you're no nearer to finding the killer?
No. (Sips his drink contemplatively) He’s playing with us.
returns.
Playing? I hope you two aren't planning more games for
later. If I remember correctly, last time, Victor, you Managed to fleece me out of a great deal of money!
(Quietly) No... no.
Is something amiss?
sac oEae (Trying to brighten the mood) We're fine, John. Is dinner ready?
Indeed it is!
Good! I’m famished. I swear I could eat a horse.
(Deadpan) It is funny that you should say that...
They laugh.
Well, a lady should never arrive at the table unescorted. If you will each take one of my arms... (To VICTOR) there... (To JOHN) thank you.
They leave the study and walk down the hall.
So, I believe you two were at the theatre the other evening.
(Laughs) Oh, wait until I tell you about it, John. Victor what did we think of (dramatically) Portentum! (She laughs)
SCENE 4: SILENCE. Silence, then very quickly...
(Whispers) I know you can hear me. (Sniggers) This should be very sudden and quiet, almost subliminal.
SCENE 5: INT. THE DINING ROOM. We hear JOHN, JACQUELINE and VICTOR approach the dining room — another clock is ticking.
(Muffled, still laughing) And they kept... oh, they kept preaking into song. (Sings in an operatic/OTT style) ‘And hence one master-passion in the breast, Like Aaron’s serpent, swallows up the rest.
(Muffled laughter) As you hear, John, I did not choose my wife for her musical abilities.
The door opens and they enter.

Oh, but it was so ridiculous. This boy was just killing people for no apparent reason. But when one of his victims rose up from the dance hall floor and began to sing... well, I wasn’t the only one laughing, was I dear?”
No. I was disappointed myself. Would have liked some kind of reason as to his motives.
Is there always a motive?
Isn’t that what you always tell me? Whenever I suggest otherwise you start quoting one of those damn books of yours!
Yes. I do not know. Recently, I have begun to wonder if
sometimes those who kill simply have a different morality to the rest of- He is interrupted by the cat squealing as he stands on it.
(Gasps) Wretched creature! Come on, get out! Out, out!
Oh, did the poor kitty get in the nasty man’s way? (She continues making ‘mewing’ noises to the cat and talking to it as JOHN and VICTOR speak)
Poor kitty nothing. I swear the animal is cursed. At night, T’m positive I’ve seen its eyes glowing as it follows me around... waiting to pounce.
If you don’t like it so, why keep it?
It was in Woolstencroft’s will. ‘I bequeath my good doctor — the man who has prolonged my life for these last few years - my house, my maid and my vicious little beast of a cat.’
(Putting down the cat) Go on then, out you go.
(Sitting down) Now shall we eat?
They sit down and begin to eat.
(Chewing) Mmmm... John... this is superb...!”
Victor! Don’t talk with your mouth full.
(Laughing) Ah... there she goes again, John! Sorry, my
blue-blooded beauty!
(Stung) Victor!
(Quickly) Would anyone like more wine? Jacqueline? You're not eating?
I don’t seem to have a knife...
(Whispers - almost subliminally) Gonna cut your throat.
Oh, I must apologise. Pll call for Jade.
Ni no, I'll go and fetch one. It will give me a chance to see more of my ancestor’s workmanship.
If you wish. But, please, I do not be long.
(Stands up) Gentlemen. JOHN and VICTOR stand. She leaves and they sit down again.
Is something wrong, Victor?!”
What do you mean, old man?
Jacqueline and yourself — you both seem... on edge.
If I didn’t know better, I'd swear you two had some sort of mystical ability, you know. (Pause) He’s killed again.
Damn! I should have been at the Sanatorium!
Cinterrupis) You wouldn’t have been able to do anything, John. You can’t save them all.
I might have been able to.
No John—
CInterrupts - agitated) I might have been able to—
(interrupts — upset) John! You are the greatest surgeon

Perfugium has ever known. Your skills are renowned throughout the town; you have saved more lives in the last ten years than many would believe possible. But... but there is nothing even you could do for a girl whose throat has been sliced so savagely as to make her head almost separate from her body. Even you could not save one whose chest has been ripped open and her heart removed. Her heart... (He trails off, unable to speak)
moves over to him.
(Quietly) Here... have some more wine.

(Quietly) I’m sorry, old friend. I do not know why this one is affecting me more than the others. In our professions, John, we see death every. day but - I am sorry this is supposed to be a night of celebration.”
pours more wine.
(Passing the wine to VICTOR) Victor, my ersatz birthday fails in comparison to the unnatural taking of a human life.
I had to tell her family. I had to... I destroyed that family.
Do you know what that must, be like? Well, of course you don’t. (Slightly bitterly) You have no family.’

You and Jacqueline have been my family since I arrived here. You have cared for me and shown me love and friendship that I do not even know if I deserve. If I even try to imagine my life without you two... well, I can’t.
(Drinks his wine) I’m sorry, old man. Must be getting old. Letting the job get to me. Would you mind if I got terribly drunk?

(Laughs) It’s my birthday and my house and so I say we shall all get ‘terribly drunk’ and you can forget about work, Jacqueline can forget about the Hostel and I shall forget about my dark past and we will have a good night even if it kills us to do so.
SCENE 6: SILENCE. Silence, then very quickly...
(Whispers) You're going to die tonight. (Sniggers) This should be very sudden and quiet, almost subliminal.
SCENE 7: A CORRIDOR.
is walking, her footsteps keeping the beat of the clock from the previous scene.
(Calling out) Jade! Jade!
(From a distance) I’m coming, ma’am.
(Shivers, then to herself) Cold...”
The whispering voice — sniggers — by now this is becoming more noticeable.
(Calling out) Where are you?
We hear a sound of scratching against woodwork.
(From a distance) In the scullery, ma’am. I'm coming. The scratching gets louder.
What is that?
(From a distance) What’s what, ma’am?
The scratching gets louder and more frantic.
SAC! Hello? Is somebody there?

The scratching gets louder and JACQUELINE stops walking. Her footsteps stop, the sound of her heartbeat fades up, getting faster. The scratching gets louder and more frantic and seems to be coming from all around her.
(Starting to panic) What is that? Who’s there?
(Suddenly loud in JACQUELINE’s ear) Ma’am?
The heartbeat stops and the scratching becomes quiet.
(Gasps) Jade!
Ma'am?
That noise...
I’m afraid there might be some mice in the house, ma’am.
Unfortunately the cat seems more interested in following the Master than in catching rodents. Are you—
(Interrupts) I’m fine. Now, the reason I called you is because the table has not been set correctly.
Ma'am? JACQUELINE The table... My knife is missing.
That's not possible!
(Shocked at a servant speaking this way) 1 beg your
pardon!
I’m sorry, ma’am. I mean... I set three places. The Master,
yourvelt and Inspector Schaeffer. Three forks, three spoons, and three ves.
Well then, my knife would appear to have vanished into
thin air. Perhaps you’d be so good as to fetch me another one.
JADE Of course.
They start walking.
I will bring it to the dining room, ma‘am.
I'd like a word with you first.
Ma’am?
How old are you, Jade?
I will be twenty next month, ma’am.
Twenty? That's very young.
I was working for the old Master
(interrupts) Mr Woolstencroft?
That's right, ma’am. I joined Mr Woolstencroft’s service on my fourteenth birthday and then, after his death, I stayed on for the new Master. JACQUELINE And how do you find your new Master?
He is a good man. And very learned. He’s not like the men from the town. He reads books!
Books, eh? Well!
Is something wrong, ma’am? Only you seem — oh, here’s the kitchens, I'll fetch you that knife.
opens the door and they enter the scullery as they continue talking.
How much do you know about your new Master, Jade?
I know there is a mystery about him, but that is all. aye if you could tell me more..
John Smith is a wonderful man. He is the Kindest, most porters man I have ever met.
But Inspector Schaeffer—
(Interrupts with an embarrassed giggle) Oh, of course, except for the good Inspector. But we know where Inspector Schaeffer came from, don’t we?”
I’m not sure I understand, ma’am. Here’s your knife.
Thank you. I know your Master’s appearance is, at first, off-putting and I know that his amnesia can cause worry as to what his past—
CInterrupts, struggling with the word) ‘Amnesia’ ma’am?”

His lack of memory. (Beat) Let me explain. Doctor John Smith, was found wandering the streets of Perfugium ten years ago today. He has no memory of his previous life, no memory of who he was. Because of his physical appearance we believe he may have survived a terrible accident, perhaps a fire. We do know that he is clearly a good man My husband and I are here for his birthday.”
Birthday? But if he has no memory—
Indeed. This is not his real birthday. This is a celebration of the ten years he has spent in our town.
I did not know any of that, ma’am, thank you. May I ask...
Yes?
Well... he does not know where he is from?”
That’s correct. He is a man of mystery and I know (Pauses) I know how intriguing that can be to a young woman.
He is an intriguing gentleman.
Yes... he is. Of course, he wouldn't be interested in a girl such as yourself.
(Shocked) Ma‘am, I-
(interrupts) Oh, please do not take offence. I’m sure a pretty young girl like you has the pick of many a young man. It’s just
that I know of a number of young women who have believed that because of his missing memory, because of his physical disability... well, Tm sure we understand each other.
I think we do, ma‘am. If you'll excuse me, I must prepare dessert.
Oh good! What is it?
Marinated figs with a raspberry coulis. The Master’s favourite.
Wonderful. If you'll excuse me...
JADE Of course, ma’am.
leaves the kitchen. Fade down.
SCENE 8: INT. THE DINING ROOM. Fade up as VICTOR talking. The clock ticking. They are all eating and talking boisterously.
.. well, I don’t understand it, I really don’t.
it’s who I am.
But to consort with criminals?
Oh, come on now, Victor. We cannot categorise them so simply.
It is a fact universally acknowledged that those without
homes or a decent family upbringing descend rapidly into a criminal lifestyle. Pickpockets, prostitutes and the rest.
But if we try and help them—
(interrupts) Which is very noble, my dear, but why you? Why do you feel the need, with your privileged upbringing, to run a hostel for them?
Perhaps because of my upbringing? Since I was a child, I have had it drummed into me that I am somehow superior
CInterrupts) Ah! So, it is out of guilt?
(Laughing) And I thought I was the one who always looked for motives, Victor!
But I would never talk down to another merely because of their upbringing...
Her voice merges into the following lines as the conversation and the evening continues.
..crime, crime, crime! I mean, what say you, John?””
I’m afraid I agree with your wife. I believe that all life is precious. I am surprised you feel otherwise. I thought you disapproved of social superiority.

It’s not that. I’m not explaining myself very well. It is not what you are born into but what you do with your life. The girl today... the girl we found. She wasn’t a whore like the others. Do not tell me that. her life was therefore not of more importance!l”*
JACQUELINE Of course it wasn’t! The others may have been-

Cinterrupts) Be honest, Jacqueline! Who of us here does not place such judgements? We hear of a death. Our first reaction is one of sadness. We then discover that the victim was a prostitute or a member of a criminal gang and we immediately, almost unconsciously,
fee] that it is therefore of less importance. That, perhaps, in some small way, they deserved it.
Much as I hate to agree, agree I must. Perhaps, it is part of what makes us... human. However, I do believe that Jacqueline’s work is imperative if we are to improve...
Again his voice merges into the following lines as the evening moves forward.
JACQUELINE And you still have had no luck?

No. I must have read a thousand or more books in an attempt to jog my memory. I have visited hypnotists, and specialists, and only the Empress knows who else, and yet still I have found no way to light the darkness in my mind. But let us not dwell on it. Not tonight.
enters.
Aah! Here’s Jade with dessert! More wine, Victor?
Again his voice merges into the folowing lines as the evening moves forward.
.» and so I said, ‘Fetch me everything on the menu!’ They all laugh.
(Laughing) How they must appreciate your patronage, Victor!
(Laughing) Victor! Are you drunk?
What? No. No, no, no, no! Well, yes actually...
They all laugh.
But while I am standing. (He stumbles) Oops!
(Laughing) Just about!
I want to make a speech... no, a toast! (Seriously) These

last few days have not been easy for us. John, old friend, you have been ill and are no nearer to understanding what... well, what you are! I have seen... seen things I would not wish on anyone... and I don't just mean that blasted musical!
They laugh.
But... but tonight is a night to forget all that and to... well let’s have no more talk of death!
Hear he-
(interrupts) Or curses!
Quite—
CInterrupts) Or proph— procephies... prophecies!
I think-
CInterrupts) And let us celebrate! It’s good old Doctor
John Smith’s birthday! (His voice starts turning nastier) Except it isn’t of course.
A heartbeat starts to fade up, getting louder and faster.
(Amused) I’m sorry, John. He was drinking before we arrived here.
(Whispers) You know what he is!
(Suddenly shrieks) The blood! I can smell it on my hands!
(Terrified) Victor! John, perhaps-
CInterrupts shrieking) Shut up! Don’t turn to him! He

doesn’t even know who he is! Who are you John, ‘old friend'? You can’t remember! What are you hiding? And look at you! What are you? (He throws his glass at the wall causing JACQUELINE to scream. Shouts) What are you?
The heartbeat suddenly stops as VICTOR falls silent.
(Quietly) Dear God... John, I am so sorry. I don’t even know what I’m saying...” ;
Victor? What's happening to you?
I don’t... I don’t know! John! I am so truly sorty., Please, I must have drunk more wine than I thought. Please forgive me!*
John?
I did not know you thought this way, Victor.
I don’t! It’s as if something is in my head... (The whispering voice sniggers) trying to... I cannot apologise enough John! JOHN And you, Jacqueline? Do you believe that I am hiding something?
No. of course not! And neither does Victor. Do you, Victor?
No! Please, old friend!*'
You are obviously under a great deal of pressure. The
horrors you have seen recently must have... well, it must be very difficult. But, I assure you, Victor, I am not trying to hide anything. I
would give anything to know my past. Anything to know what... who I am.
1 know you would! I don’t understand why I... perhaps I should seek medical help... I don’t...
d0nN (Humorously) And now you're questioning my skills as a doctor?
(Laughs) No, of course not. (Quieter) I am sorry.
It is partly my fault. Home-made wine is always stronger...
Yes... perhaps I should not have drunk so much.*”
It is forgotten. The murders are making you see shadows

where there are none. You see the world... no you see people as good or bad... law-abiding citizens or criminals... and you believe that it is something in them that causes them to be this way. Perhaps, because we do not Know what I was, you find it harder to categorise me?
But I do know. You are a good doctor and a damn good friend! Why would I wish- 7
(Interrupts) Please, let us think nothing of it. We should
retire to the study.
(Still quite shocked) Ob yes... and there’s your present...
(Drily) Really? 1 assumed Victor’s performance there was my gift. An extract from Portentum, no?
laughs but still shocked at his own outburst.
Just promise me one thing, Victor?
(Desperate) Anything John.
Don’t start singing!
SCENE 9: THE KITCHEN.
Fade up. JADE is washing the dishes. She is humming the ‘Zagreus’ tune and then gradually the words come to her.
(Singing to herself) ‘They say he sits inside your head, and he sees you in your bed...’ (Pauses) What a strange tune! Now what do you suppose put that in my head, eh???
The cat mews.
No... no, of course you don’t know. You're only a cat! Now,
let’s see if the Master left some food for you... (continues singing) ‘... and eats you when you're sleeping... 34 Fade down just as the whispering voice sniggers once more.
SCENE 10: INT. THE STUDY. Fade up. The clock is ticking and we can hear the wind starting to pick up outside.
That wind is really starting to pick up!
Yes. It doesn’t sound too pleasant, does it? John, thank you for being so understanding about earlier.
Victor, you’re my oldest friend. You helped keep me sane
when my mind was empty. I owe you so much.
(Coughs) Ah-hem!
JOHN And you too, of course. But, as tonight is my birthday I feel that it should be all about me! Enough talk about you two! I would like to open my present!
I’m not sure if it’s such a good idea now...
Come on! What is it?
It’s just tonight... well... what is it you want more than anything John?
JOHN A bottomless pot of gold and dominion over all of Perfugium!
laughs a fake, OTT evil laugh which VICTOR joins in with.
No, really. I’m being serious.”
Well. . to know who I am. To know what I have forgotten.
takes the present and hands it to JOHN.
Well... perhaps this will oh, it seems silly now after everything else that’: s happening but—
CInterrupts intrigued) What is it?™
Yesterday, at the Hostel, we had a visitor. A remarkable man whom we helped. So he gave me these!
She pours the stones onto the table.
